sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 19/2100Z
sections.text: TO 20/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5528 (N21W70) PRODUCED AN X1/3B FLARE THAT MAXED AT 1508 UT. AN ERUPTIVE PROMINENCE ON THE LIMB WITH THE FLARE EXTENDED TO 0.55 SOLAR RADII. RADIO BURSTS AND SWEEPS ASSOCIATED WITH THE EVENT WERE NOT IMPRESSIVE ALTHOUGH A MODERATE TYPE IV SWEEP PRECEDED THE FLARE ONSET. FLARE LOOPS AND A BRIGHT SURGE ON THE DISK WERE ALSO OBSERVED. A DARK FILAMENT NEAR S33W23 ERUPTED BETWEEN 1237 AND 1500 UT. THE ERUPTION WAS CAUGHT IN PROGRESS ON THE BOULDER PHOTO TAKEN AT 1417 UT. TWO NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED. REGION 5554 (S26W04) EMERGED ON THE DISK LATE ON 19 JUNE AND REGION 5555 (N26E74) ROTATED OVER THE EAST LIMB TODAY. 5555 IS LOCATED NEAR THE POSITIONS OF OLD REGIONS 5506 AND 5507. SURGING ON THE EAST LIMB NEAR S18 MAY BE ASSOCIATED WITH THE RETURN OF OLD REGION 5511.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE.  SIGNIFICANT FLARES ARE POSSIBLE FROM REGION 5528 UNTIL IT IS AT LEAST ONE DAY BEYOND WEST LIMB PASSAGE.  NO OTHER REGION ON THE VISIBLE DISK HAS THE IMPRESSIVE QUALITIES USUALLY ASSOCIATED WITH MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 19/2100Z TO 20/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. PERIODS AT MINOR STORM LEVELS WERE REPORTED AFTER 0900 UT. THIS ACTIVITY IS ATTRIBUTED TO THE EFFECTS OF MAJOR FLARES ON 16 AND 17 JUNE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY UNSETTLED TOMORROW AND THE NEXT DAY, BUT IS EXPECTED TO REACH MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS ON JUNE 23 AND 24 IN RESPONSE TO TODAY'S FLARE AND/OR FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 20/2100Z
sections.text: TO 21/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH DURING THE PAST 24 HOURS OWING TO AN M9/1N FLARE FROM REGION 5528 (N20W90) ON 20 JUNE THAT MAXED AT 2214 UT. A 32-MINUTE DURATION TYPE IV SWEEP AND AN EVENT-LEVEL RADIO BURST AT 10 CM ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. REGION 5528 CROSSED THE WEST LIMB TODAY, ACCOMPANIED BY SURGING AND CORONAL RAIN.  OTHER FLARE ACTIVITY INCLUDED TWO M-CLASS FLARES FROM REGIONS 5552 (S18E51) AND 3 M-CLASS FLARES FROM REGION 5555 (N25E53). BOTH 5552 AND 5555 ARE MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. FIVE NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED. FOUR OF THEM CAME OVER THE EAST LIMB, 3 IN THE NORTH AND ONE IN THE SOUTH, AND ONE EMERGED ON THE DISK. A FILAMENT LOCATED NEAR N15W05 ON 20 JUNE AT 1417 UT DISAPPEARED BEFORE 1308 UT TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. BOTH 5552 AND 5555 CONTAIN THE POTENTIAL FOR M-CLASS X-RAY EVENTS, AND ADDITIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN THESE REGIONS COULD LEAD TO X-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 20/2100Z TO 21/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN MOSTLY QUIET FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE LAST PERIOD AT ACTIVE LEVELS WAS 2100-2400 UT ON 20 JUNE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO PERSIST AT QUIET LEVELS UNTIL 23 JUNE, WHEN MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS MAY COMMENCE.  THIS ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED IN RESPONSE TO THE MAJOR FLARES AND SIGNIFICANT FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE THAT OCCURRED ON 20 JUNE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 21/2100Z
sections.text: TO 22/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW DURING THE LAST 24 HOURS. REGION 5555 (N26E40) DEVELOPED IN BOTH WHITE LIGHT AND H-ALPHA AND MAINTAINED ITS MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY.  REGION 5552 (S18E33) HAS BEEN DIVIDED INTO TWO REGIONS AND IS NO LONGER MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. THERE ARE NOW 19 SPOTTED GROUPS ON THE VISIBLE DISK BUT ONLY 4 OF THEM ARE CONSIDERED ERUPTIVE AT THIS TIME. THREE NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED TODAY. TWO OF THEM ARE NEAR THE SOUTHEAST LIMB BEHIND REGION 5552.  THE THIRD, 5562 (N38E46), EMERGED ON THE DISK.  THERE WAS SURGING ON THE NORTHWEST LIMB NEAR THE POSITION OF DEPARTED REGION 5528, AND A LARGE ACTIVE PROMINENCE WAS VISIBLE ON THE SOUTHEAST LIMB.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. REGION 5555 POSSESSES THE POTENTIAL FOR SIGNIFICANT (M-CLASS) FLARES AND COULD PRODUCE X-CLASS ACTIVITY IF GROWTH CONTINUES.  THE COMPLEX OF REGIONS IN THE SOUTHEAST QUADRANT (INCLUDING 5552) SHOULD ALSO BE WATCHED FOR ADDITIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE NEXT TWO DAYS IN RESPONSE TO THE MAJOR FLARES AND THE SIGNIFICANT FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE THAT OCCURRED ON 20 JUNE. STORM CONDITIONS SHOULD SUBSIDE BY THE THIRD DAY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 29/2100Z
sections.text: TO 30/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. MOST OF TODAY'S FLARE PRODUCTION WAS FROM REGION 5569 (N21W27), A FAIRLY LARGE, MAGNETICALLY COMPLICATED REGION. IN ADDITION TO NUMEROUS C-CLASS FLARES THE REGION PRODUCED AN M2/SN 1502Z AND AN M2/SN AT 1739Z. THE GROUP APPEARS TO HAVE A DELTA CON- FIGURATION IN THE TRAILER AND IS SLOWLY DECAYING AND ELONGATING. REGION 5555 (N26W60) PRODUCED THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE DAY, AN M3/2B AT 29/2127Z WHICH WAS ACCOMPANIED BY LOOPS, MODERATE DISCRETE RADIO BURSTS, AND A STRONG TYPE IV SWEEP. THE REGION COOLED SIGNIFICANTLY THEREAFTER AND DID NOT PRODUCE ANY MORE FLARES. NEW REGION 5572 (S16E68) ROTATED INTO VIEW TODAY AND PRODUCED AN M3 EVENT AT 0616Z. THE X-RAY LEVELS WERE ENHANCED THROUGH 0923Z AND LOOPS WERE VISIBLE ON THE LIMB FROM 0622- 1455Z. THE REGION APPERAS TO BE A SMALL D-TYPE GROUP. THE REMAINDER OF THE SOLAR DISK AND LIMBS WERE RELATIVELY QUIET.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. THE MAIN THREATS FOR MODERATE LEVELS ARE REGION 5563 (THE LARGEST GROUP ON THE DISK), REGION 5569, AND REGION 5572. THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR HIGH LEVELS OF ACTIVITY FROM REGION 5569.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 29/2100Z TO 30/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS GENERALLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED. A PERIOD OF UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE CONDITIONS OCCURRED FROM 0130-0900Z. ENERGETIC PARTICLE MONITORS DETECTED AN ENHANCE- MENT IN THE >10MEV RANGE FROM 29/2230-30/1500Z. EVENT LEVELS WERE ATTAINED BRIEFLY BETWEEN 0655-0725Z WITH A PEAK FLUX OF 17 PFU AT 0710Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TOMORROW AND ARE EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE FOR THE SECOND AND THIRD DAYS. THE INCREASE IN ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED AS A RESULT OF THE M3/2B FLARE AT 29/2127Z MENTIONED ABOVE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 30/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. FLARE ACTIVITY WAS REMARKABLY REDUCED DURING THE PERIOD WITH ONLY OCCASIONAL SUBFLARES ALL OF WHICH WERE X-RAY CLASS C1 OR LESS. REGION 5569 (N21W39) IN PARTICULAR EXHIBITED STEADY, QUIET DECAY AND SIMPLIFICATION. MINOR SURGE ACTIVITY WAS OBSERVED ON WEST LIMB AT N20 AND EAST LIMB AT N08. THE REMAINDER OF THE DISK WAS QUIET AND STABLE.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 5569 IS CONSIDERED TO BE THE PRIMARY THREAT FOR M-CLASS EVENTS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 30/2100Z TO 01/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED FROM THE BEGIN- NING OF THE DAY UNTIL SHORTLY AFTER 1500Z WHEN THE CONDITIONS ATTAINED ACTIVE TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS. THE FIRST INDICATION OF ACTIVITY WAS A SUDDEN IMPULSE AT ABOUT 0730Z. THE BOULDER MAGNETOMETER RECORDED A 34 NANOTESLA JUMP AT THAT TIME. THE DISTURBANCE WAS MOST LIKELY CAUSED BY THE M3/2B FLARE WHICH OCCURRED AT 29/2127Z. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PARTICLE CHAN- NELS ALSO RECORDED PERIODS OF ENHANCED FLUXES DURING THE PERIOD AND ATTAINED EVENT LEVEL FROM 0655-1030Z WITH A PEAK FLUX OF 17 PFU AT 0720Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE WITH PERIODS OF STORM CONDITIONS TOMOR- ROW AS THE CURRENT DISTURBANCE PERSISTS. ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE ON THE SECOND AND THIRD DAYS DUE TO EFFECTS FROM A HIGH SPEED SOLAR WIND STREAM WHICH IS EXPECTED TO IMPACT THE EARTH AT THAT TIME. EVIDENCE FOR THE STREAM IN- CLUDES A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE (L=220, S30-S45), PIONEER-VENUS SOLAR WIND DATA, AND RECURRENCE.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE TOMORROW AND MOSTLY ACTIVE FOR THE SECOND AND THIRD DAYS. THE INCREASE IS EXPECTED IN RESPONSE TO A HIGH SPEED SOLAR WIND STREAM ORIGINATING FROM A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 24/2100Z
sections.text: TO 25/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH.  AN X2/2N FLARE OCCURRED AT 25/0844UT FROM REGION 5603 (N28W90).  THIS WAS A RELATIVELY IMPULSIVE EVENT BUT WAS ACCOMPANIED BY STRONG TYPE II AND IV SWEEP AND SMALL DISCREET BURSTS.  PROTONS WERE OBSERVED AT EARTH WITHIN 20 MINUTES OF THE START OF THE FLARE.  REGION 5603 IS NOW BEYOND THE WEST LIMB, BUT HAS BEEN VERY ACTIVE PRODUCING SMALL C LEVEL FLARES AND BRIGHT SURGES.  OTHER REGIONS OF INTEREST INCLUDE REGIONS 5597 (S13W56) AND 5598 (S22W42).  REGION 5598 IS GROWING AND HAS SOME MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY.  THE EASTERN HEMI- SPHERE IS NEARLY VOID OF SPOTS AND THE EAST LIMB IS QUIET.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE.  THERE IS A CHANCE FOR ANOTHER ENERGETIC EVENT FROM REGION 5603.  HOWEVER, SINCE THE REGION IS BEYOND THE WEST LIMB OF THE SUN, REGION AND ANY SUBSEQUENT FLARE MEASUREMENTS WILL BE LIMITED.  ISOLATED CLASS M FLARES ARE POSSIBLE FROM REGIONS 5597 AND 5598.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 24/2100Z TO 25/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.  A SMALL BUT ENERGETIC PROTON EVENT ASSOCIATED WITH THE X2 FLARE MENTIONED IN PART 1A, BEGAN AT 25/0900UT.  THIS EVENT RESULTED IN A SMALL ENHANCEMENT ON THE THULE NEUTRON MONITOR, THE FIRST NOTABLE GROUND LEVEL ENHANCEMENT THIS SOLAR CYCLE.  P10 PEAK FLUX WAS 54 PFU AT 25/1225UT.  PARTICLE FLUXES ARE NOW DECLINING.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE DUE PRIMARILY TO THE CORONAL HOLE LOCATED NEAR N30W40.  THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR AN INCREASE IN ACTIVITY LATE IN THE PERIOD FROM THE X2 FLARE.

sections.text: TO 26/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW, ONLY SMALL C LEVEL FLARES HAVE BEEN OBSERVED.  ACTIVITY FROM DEPARTING REGION 5603 (N28 WEST LIMB) HAS DECREASED AND WAS PROBABLY RESPONSIBLE FOR MANY OF THE UNCORRELATED C FLARES EARLY IN THE DAY.  REGIONS 5597 (S13W69) AND 5598 (S23W55) APPEAR TO BE DECLINING, ALTHOUGH AFS HAD BEEN REPORTED.  THE MOST ACTIVE REGION AT THIS TIME IS REGION 5608 (S19E20).  REGION 5611 (S38W20) WAS NUMBERED AND ANOTHER REGION MAY BE ROTATING ON TO THE DISK NEAR S20.  THE 10.7CM RADIO FLUX IS DOWN TO 164, THE LOWEST VALUE SINCE MARCH.

sections.text: LOW.  THERE IS A SMALL CHANCE OF AN ISOLATED CLASS M FLARE FROM THE REGIONS IN THE SOUTHWEST AND FROM THE RETURNING REGIONS ON THE EAST LIMB.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 08/2100Z
sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW.  REGION 5629 (S17W07) IS STILL THE MOST IMPRESSIVE REGION ON THE DISK.  THIS REGION IS LARGE (OVER 1300 MILLIONTHS), COMPLEX (EKC WITH DELTAS), AND DYNAMIC (AFS, ADF, AND NUMEROUS BRIGHTENINGS) BUT SURPRISINGLY, FLARE ACTIVITY HAS BEEN LOW.  HOWEVER, THIS MAY BE CHANGING. REGION 5629 PRODUCED THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE DAY A C9.2/1N AT 09/1429UT AND IS SHOWING SIGNS OF FRAGMENTING.  IT IS THE MAIN CONTRIBUTOR TO THE HIGH RADIO FLUX VALUES BEING OBSERVED. REGION 5622 (S26W64) THE M FLARE PRODUCER A FEW DAYS AGO APPEARS TO BE DECLINING AS IT APPROACHES THE WEST LIMB.  REGION 5639 (N28E69) APPEARS TO BE THE RETURN OF REGION 5603 (N28 L-360), WHICH PRODUCED AN X2 PROTON FLARE ON ITS WEST LIMB TRANSIT ON 25 JULY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE.  REGION 5629 IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE AT LEAST ONE MAJOR FLARE BEFORE ITS WEST LIMB TRANSIT ON 16 AUGUST.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 08/2100Z TO 09/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.  A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 21 GAMMAS WAS OBSERVED AT 09/1831UT PROBABLY A RESULT OF THE M7.6/1B FLARE ON 07 AUG AT 2058UT.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED FOR THE NEAR FUTURE. THERE IS A CHANCE FOR A PROTON EVENT.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 09/2100Z
sections.text: TO 10/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5629 (S18W19) PRODUCED AN M1/1N AT 10/0216Z. THIS EVENT HAD TWO PEAKS AND MINOR RADIO BURSTS. THE REMAINDER OF THE ACTIVITY CONSISTED OF SEVERAL LOW CLASS C FLARES FROM 5629 AND SUBFLARES FROM REGION 5639 (N28E58) AND OTHER REGIONS. TWO SMALL REGIONS WERE NUMBERED - 5640 (N13E62) AND 5641 (N19E77).

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD CONTINUE
sections.text: AT A MODERATE LEVEL. REGION 5629 REMAINS AS THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE FOR CLASS M AND X FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 09/2100Z TO 10/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT PREDOMINANTLY MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. A BRIEF PERIOD OF MAJOR STORMING OCCURRED AT HIGH LATITUDES DURING 10/0900-1200Z. THIS DISTURBANCE IS ATTRIBUTED TO AN M7/1N FROM S26W38 AT 07/2058Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST: GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: CONDITIONS SHOULD MODERATE OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS FROM SLIGHTLY ACTIVE TO PREDOMINANTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS. A PROMPT ARRIVAL PROTON EVENT IS POSSIBLE FROM A MAJOR EVENT IN REGION 5629 SINCE THIS REGION IS ROTATING INTO FAVORABLE LONGITUDES FOR THAT OCCURRENCE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 11/2100Z
sections.text: TO 12/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5629 (S16W44) PRODUCED A POWERFUL X2/2B AT 12/1427Z. STRONG TYPE II, MODERATE TYPE IV, AND STRONG CENTIMETER BURSTS ACCOMPANIED THIS LONG DURATION FLARE. REGION 5629 ALSO PRODUCED AN M5/1B AT 11/2302Z, AN M1/SF AT 12/0307Z, AND AN M2/1N AT 12/0802Z. NO SIGNIFICANT RADIO BURSTS ACCOMPANIED THESE LESSER FLARES. REGION 5629 MAINTAINS ITS LARGE SUNSPOT AREA AND MIXED MAGNETIC POLARITIES. REGION 5643 (N15E62) IS A MODERATE SIZE CLASS E GROUP WHICH NOW APPEARS AS BIPOLAR. NEW REGION 5644 (N22E82) IS ROTATING OVER THE EAST LIMB.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BE AT A
sections.text: GENERALLY MODERATE LEVEL. REGION 5629 REMAINS A THREAT TO PRODUCE ANOTHER CLASS X FLARE OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. INFREQUENT CLASS M FLARES CAN BE EXPECTED FROM REGION 5643.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 11/2100Z TO 12/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS UNSETTLED. A SATELLITE PROTON EVENT BEGAN AT 12/1600Z. A MAXIMUM FLUX OF 800 P.F.U. WAS OBSERVED AT THE END OF THE PERIOD AND LEVELS WERE STILL CLIMBING AT THAT TIME. A POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT BEGAN AT 12/1800Z AND A MAXIMUM ABSORPTION OF 8DB WAS OBSERVED, ALSO AT THE END OF THE REPORTING PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE UNSETTLED UNTIL THE LATTER HALF OF 13 AUG WHEN STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN AS A RESULT OF THE FLARE ACTIVITY ON 11 AND 12 AUG. MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE FORECAST FOR 14 AUG, RELENTING SOMEWHAT TO MINOR STORM LEVELS ON 15 AUG. STORMING ON 14-15 AUG IS FORECAST IN RESPONSE TO THE X2 FLARE ON 12 AUGUST. THE SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AND PCA ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE DURING 13 AUG.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 12/2100Z
sections.text: TO 13/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5629 (S17W56) PRODUCED AN M1/1F AT 13/0722Z WITH MINOR RADIO BURSTS. REGION 5629 UNDERWENT SOME DECAY AFTER ITS X2/2B FLARE ON 12 AUG. REGION 5643 (N16E51) GREW DURING THE PERIOD AND IS NOW A MODERATE TO LARGE CLASS E SUNSPOT GROUP. FREQUENT SUBFLARES WERE REPORTED FROM THIS REGION.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD
sections.text: CONTINUE AT A GENERALLY MODERATE LEVEL. ANOTHER MAJOR FLARE IS STILL POSSIBLE FROM REGION 5629 PRIOR TO ITS WEST LIMB TRANSIT. REGION 5643 SHOULD BEGIN TO PRODUCE MORE IN THE WAY OF CLASS M FLARES AND CLASS X FLARES ARE BECOMING MORE LIKELY FROM THIS REGION.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 12/2100Z TO 13/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS GENERALLY UNSETTLED DURING THE PERIOD. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON EVENT WHICH BEGAN AT 12/1600UT REACHED A MAXIMUM FLUX OF 9200 P.F.U. AT 13/0710Z. THAT LEVEL IS THE HIGHEST RECORDED SINCE THE GREAT PROTON EVENT OF AUG 1972 BUT THE CURRENT EVENT IS ABOUT ONE SIXTH THE PEAK FLUX OBSERVED 17 YEARS AGO. AT THE END OF THE PERIOD, THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV FLUX HAD DECAYED TO 6200 P.F.U. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT REMAINS IN PROGRESS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  A MAJOR GEOMAGNETIC
sections.text: STORM IS EXPECTED TO BEGIN SOON AND CONTINUE DURING 14 AUG. GENERALLY MINOR STORM LEVELS ARE PREDICTED FOR 15 AUG AND ACTIVE LEVELS SHOULD BE EXPERIENCED ON 16 AUG. THE PROTON EVENT AND POLAR CAP ABSORPTION SHOULD CONTINUE DURING 14 AUG.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 13/2100Z
sections.text: TO 14/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5629 (S17W72) PRODUCED AN X3/3B TENFLARE WITH TYPE II AND IV AT 0053Z. DISCRETE BURSTS IN THE THOUSANDS OF FLUX UNITS WERE RECORDED ACROSS THE RADIO SPECTRUM. THE REGION ALSO GENERATED AN M2/1N AT 1924Z. REGION 5643 (N16E35), SIMILAR IN SIZE AND STRUCTURE TO 5629, YIELDED AN M1/1N AT 1016Z. REGION 5645 (N28E62) ALSO CONTRIBUTED AN M1/1F AT 1205Z.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGIONS 5629 AND 5643 BOTH REMAIN OMINOUS AND ARE CAPABLE OF ISOLATED CLASS-X ACTIVITY. REGION 5645 MAY PRODUCE M-LEVEL FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 13/2100Z TO 14/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS SINCE THE SUDDEN COMMENCEMENT AT 0614Z. THE IMPULSE, MEASURED AT 64 NANOTESLAS AT BOULDER, IS THOUGHT TO BE THE RESULT OF THE X2/2B FLARE OF 12/1427Z. BOTH THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND SATELLITE PROTON EVENTS CONTINUED ALL DAY BUT BOTH ARE SUBSIDING. THERE WAS NO DISCERNIBLE INCREASE IN PROTON FLUXES EARLIER TODAY AFTER THE X3/3B EVENT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT PREDOMINANTLY ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. AUGUST 16 SHOULD BE THE MOST DISTURBED DAY OF THE INTERVAL. THE X3/3B FLARE OF EARLIER TODAY SHOULD AFFECT THE MAGNETO- SPHERE AT THAT TIME.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 14/2100Z
sections.text: TO 15/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5629 (S16W84) YIELDED YET ANOTHER X-CLASS FLARE, THIS ONE AN X1/0F AT 0315Z. LARGE DISCRETE FREQUENCY RADIO BURSTS (16,000 SFU AT 2695 MHZ) AND A VERY LONG-LIVED TYPE IV SWEEP ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. THE REGION ALSO PRODUCED AN M3/1N AT 1409Z AND IS THE PROBABLE SOURCE OF AN M5 AT 2051Z. REGION 5643 (N15E23), LARGE AND COMPLEX AGAIN TODAY, GENERATED ONLY SUBFLARES THE LAST 24 HOURS. ONE OR TWO NEW SPOT GROUPS ARE ROTATING ONTO THE DISK IN THE NORTHEAST BUT ARE AS YET UNNUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: AT THE MODERATE TO HIGH LEVEL THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD. WATCH WEST LIMB FOR AN EVENTFUL DEPARTURE OF REGION 5629 AND CENTER DISK FOR ENERGETIC ACTIVITY FROM REGION 5643.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 14/2100Z TO 15/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. RECENT X-CLASS FLARE ACTIVITY FROM REGION 5629 IS THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE DISTURBANCE. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND SATELLITE PROTON EVENTS ARE STILL IN PROGRESS. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF ABOUT 50 NANOTESLAS WAS OBSERVED AT BOULDER AT 2018Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR STORM LEVELS THROUGH 17 AUGUST. TODAY'S X1 FLARE SHOULD PROLONG THE CURRENT DISTURBANCE UNTIL THEN. UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE ANTICIPATED AT THE END OF THE PERIOD. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND SATELLITE PROTON EVENTS SHOULD PERSIST FOR PERHAPS ANOTHER 24 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 15/2100Z
sections.text: TO 16/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5629 (S11W92) PRODUCED AN ESTIMATED X20/2N FLARE AT 0118Z. THE VALUE FOR THIS X-RAY EVENT IS ESTIMATED DUE TO DETECTOR SATURATION. THE X20 WAS ACCOMPANIED BY MAJOR DISCRETE FREQUENCY BURSTS ACROSS THE SPECTRUM (5400 SFU AT 2695 MHZ) AND A STRONG TYPE IV SWEEP. THIS LONG DURATION FLARE LASTED APPROXIMATELY 13 HOURS. IN ADDITION THIS REGION YIELDED AN M4/SF FLARE AT 2148Z. REGIONS 5643 (N17E09) AND 5645 (N28E36) CONTINUED TO SHOW COMPLEXITY AND DISPLAYED DELTA CONFIGURATIONS. NEW REGION 5648 (N07W20) WAS NUMBERED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5629 MAY PRODUCE MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY AS IT ROTATES OVER THE WEST LIMB. REGIONS 5643 AND 5645 SHOW THE POTENTIAL TO PRODUCE M-CLASS FLARE ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 15/2100Z TO 16/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT UNSETTLED TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. MAJOR AND MINOR STORM LEVELS OCCURRED DURING THE FIRST HALF OF THE PERIOD. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND PROTON EVENTS WERE STILL IN PROGRESS. AN ENHANCEMENT IN THE PROTON FLUX AND PCA LEVELS WAS OBSERVED IN THE WAKE OF THE X20 FLARE. A GROUND LEVEL EVENT (GLE) WAS OBSERVED WITH THE X20 FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS THROUGH 17 AUGUST WITH MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS OCCURRING DURING THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD DUE TO THE X20 FLARE FROM REGION 5629. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND PROTON EVENTS SHOULD CONTINUE THROUGH MOST OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 16/2100Z
sections.text: TO 17/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. ALTHOUGH REGION 5629 IS NOW MORE THAN A DAY BEYOND WEST LIMB AT S16 IT CONTINUES TO DOMINATE ACTIVITY. IT PRODUCED AN X2 TENFLARE AT 0122Z AND IS THE LIKELY SITE OF AN M2 WITH ASSOCIATED ERUPTIVE PROM- INENCE VISIBLE TO .5 SOLAR RADII AT 1924Z. THE MOST RECENT EVENT INCLUDED A TYPE II SWEEP. OF THE REMAINING DISK REGIONS 5645 (N28E23) AND 5643 (N15W03) ARE THE MOST IMPRESSIVE BUT NEITHER HAS BEEN PARTICULARLY FLARE-RICH. NEWLY ASSIGNED REGION 5649 (N29E52) IS WHAT WAS THOUGHT TO BE THE TRAILER SPOTS OF REGION 5647 (N27E48) BUT IS A DISTINCT BIPOLE.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. RECENT GROWTH IN REGION 5645 MAKES IT THE MOST LIKELY CANDIDATE FOR CLASS M ACTIVITY. REGION 5643 MAY ALSO PRODUCE ENERGETIC ACTIVITY AND A FINAL PARTING SHOT FROM REGION 5629 IS POSSIBLE EARLY ON.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 16/2100Z TO 17/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE UNTIL 1541Z WHEN A NEGATIVE SUDDEN IMPULSE OF ABOUT 57 NANOTESLAS WAS MEASURED AT BOULDER. ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS HAVE PREVAILED SINCE. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION AND SATELLITE PROTON EVENTS CONTINUE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS THE NEXT 48 HOURS AS A DISTURBANCE EMANATING FROM YESTERDAY'S X20 FLARE AT WEST LIMB IS DUE. UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS SHOULD PREVAIL 20 AUGUST.

sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 5643, LARGE AND SOMEWHAT COMPLEX, HAS BEEN VERY STABLE. IT SEEMS CAPABLE OF M-CLASS ACTIVITY BUT NEEDS A TRIGGER. REGION 5645 (N28E10) SIMPLIFIED DURING THE DAY BUT ALSO MAY YIELD AN ISOLATED LOW-LEVEL CLASS M FLARE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 18/2100Z
sections.text: TO 19/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 5643 (N16W15) PRODUCED THE LARGEST FLARE OF THE PERIOD: A C8/SF AT 0256Z. THIS REGION CONTINUES TO BE THE LARGEST, MOST COMPLICATED GROUP ON THE VISIBLE DISK. IT APPEARS TO BE IN A SLOW DECAY PHASE AS ITS LARGE PENUMBRAL STRUCTURE IS GRADUALLY FRAGMENTING. A LONG DURATION C8 X-RAY EVENT BEGAN AT 1913Z, ATTAINED MAXIMUM AT 2009Z AND IS DECAYING GRADUALLY AT THIS TIME. THE LACK OF ANY OPTICAL CORRELATION SUGGESTS THAT OLD REGION 5629 IS STILL MAKING ITS PRESENCE FELT, EVEN THOUGH IT IS THREE DAYS BEHIND THE LIMB. MODEST DISCRETE RADIO BURSTS AND A MODERATE TYPE II SWEEP WERE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS EVENT. THE REMAINDER OF THE DISK WAS RELATIVELY QUIET.

sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGIONS 5643 AND 5645 (N28E10) ARE THE PRIMARY THREATS FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 18/2100Z TO 19/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS OCCURRED FROM 18/2100-19/0730Z. ACTIVITY LEVELS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE DAY WERE QUIET TO UNSETTLED WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A BRIEF ACTIVE PERIOD AT HIGH LATITUDES FROM 19/1800-2100Z. A PROTON EVENT AND A PCA EVENT ARE STILL IN PROGRESS. PARTICLE FLUXES WERE DECLINING FOR MOST OF THE DAY UNTIL 1735Z WHEN A GRADUAL INCREASE BECAME APPARENT ON LOW AND HIGH ENERGY CHANNELS. THE PEAK FLUX DURING THE LAST 24 HOURS AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV WAS 150 PARTICLES AT 1920Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE TOMORROW AND GENERALLY ACTIVE FOR THE SECOND AND THIRD DAYS. INCREASED GEOMAGNETIC ACTIVITY IS POSSIBLE IN RESPONSE TO FILAMENT MATERIAL WHICH DISAPPEARED FROM THE DISK EARLY ON THE 18TH.

sections.text: TO 20/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 5643 (N16W41) PRO- DUCED TODAY'S LARGEST EVENT: A C6.9 AT 19/2138Z. THIS GROUP CONTINUES TO BE THE LARGEST ON THE DISK BUT IS DECLINING QUIETLY. sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 19/2100Z TO 20/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. CONDITIONS WERE MOSTLY QUIET AT THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD, BUT BECAME SOMEWHAT DISTURBED FROM 0600Z-1630Z. MID-LATITUDES WERE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS AND HIGH LATITUDES WERE AT MOSTLY MINOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE DISTURBANCE. CONDITIONS SUBSIDED TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE DAY. A GREATER THAN 10MEV PROTON EVENT CON- TINUES IN PROGRESS. FLUX LEVELS WERE RISING AT THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD BUT PEAKED AT 0510Z (510 PFU AT GREATER THAN 10MEV) AND HAVE BEEN DECLINING SINCE THEN. THE PCA EVENT ENDED AT ABOUT 20/1845Z.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE TOMMOROW DUE TO POSSIBLE EFFECTS FROM A DISAPPEARING FILAMENT. CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO  GRAD- UALLY SUBSIDE TO UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE SECOND AND THIRD DAYS. THE GREATER THAN 10MEV PROTON EVENT IS EXPECTED TO END SOMETIME IN THE NEXT 24 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 28/2100Z
sections.text: TO 29/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. THE HIGHLIGHT OF THE PERIOD WAS AN M6/SF AT 29/1523Z FROM REGION 5669 (S16E71). THIS LARGE, MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX GROUP ALSO PRODUCED FOUR ADDITIONAL M-CLASS FLARES: AN M4/1N AT 29/1309Z, AN M2/SF AT 29/1659Z (WHICH WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 260 SFU TENFLARE), AN M2/1B AT 29/1723Z (ASSOCIATED WITH A 200 SFU TENFLARE), AND AN M1/2B AT 29/1809Z. REGION 5669 WAS ORIGINALLY THOUGHT TO BE THE RETURN OF OLD REGION 5629 WHICH PRODUCED 5 X-CLASS FLARES ON IT'S LAST TRANSIT. HOWEVER, SUBSEQUENT ANALYSIS REVEALED THAT REGION 5669 WAS APPROXIMATELY 20 DEGREES AHEAD OF WHERE OLD 5629 SHOULD HAVE BEEN. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED M1 OCCURRED AT 29/0202Z WHICH WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A 360 SFU TENFLARE AND A SIGNIFICANT TYPE II RADIO SWEEP (VELOCITY ESTIMATED AT 1000 KM/SEC.). NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5669 PROVIDES A GOOD CHANCE FOR M-CLASS FLARES AND A FAIR CHANCE FOR AN X-CLASS FLARE. OLD REGION 5629 (MENTIONED ABOVE) WILL LIKELY RETURN TOMORROW FURTHER ENHANCING CHANCES FOR M- AND X-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 28/2100Z TO 29/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT UNSETTLED TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS AT MIDDLE LATITUDES. SPECIFICALLY, MINOR STORMING BEGAN NEAR 29/0000Z FOLLOWED BY AN INCREASE TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FROM 0600-0900Z. THEREAFTER, THE FIELD DECLINED TO UNSETTLED LEVELS. THE HIGH LATITUDE FIELD ACHIEVED MINOR STORM LEVELS NEAR 28/2230Z, REACHED SEVERE STORM LEVELS FROM 29/0300-0900Z, THEN DECLINED TO ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. THE CAUSE OF THIS DISTURBANCE WAS UNKNOWN.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT UNSETTLED LEVELS AT MIDDLE LATITUDES AND AT ACTIVE TO UNSETTLED LEVELS AT HIGHER LATITUDES.

THE CALCIUM XV EMISSIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS REGION HAVE BEEN THE STRONGEST OBSERVED DURING THE PRESENT SUNSPOT CYCLE. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED M3 X-RAY BURST OCCURRED AT 30/0317Z WHICH WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A WEAK TYPE II RADIO SWEEP. NEW REGION 5670 (S26E28) WAS ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.text: TO 31/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5669 (S16E45) REMAINED A PROLIFIC FLARE PRODUCER. sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 31/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5671 (S19E47) PRODUCED AN X2/SB FLARE AT 01/0820Z. A 360 SFU TENFLARE WAS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS FLARE. THIS VERY LARGE, EXTREMELY COMPLEX REGION ALSO PRODUCED A SN FLARE AT 01/0614Z WHICH WAS ASSOCIATED WITH FLARE LOOPS AND A 3000 SFU TENFLARE, BUT NO ACCOMPANYING X-RAY BURST. IN ADDITION, THE REGION PRODUCED A SF FLARE AT 01/1127Z ACCOMPANIED BY A 13000 SFU BURST AT 245 MHZ. THIS EVENT ALSO HAD NO APPARENT X-RAY CORRELATION. AN M1/SF FLARE AT 01/1543Z ALSO ORIGINATED WITHIN THIS REGION. REGION 5669 (S15E33) PRODUCED AN M2/1N FLARE AT 01/1501Z AND WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 270 SFU TENFLARE AND A 140000 SFU BURST AT 245 MHZ. THIS REGION IS ALSO VERY LARGE AND MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. IT IS DUE WEST OF REGION 5671. TOGETHER, THESE TWO REGIONS FORM QUITE AN IMPRESSIVE COMPLEX. SOME OBSERVATIONS SUGGEST THAT THIS COMPLEX MAY ACTUALLY BE ONE LARGE REGION. A LONG-DURATION X-RAY BURST BEGAN AT 0404Z, REACHED A MAXIMUM OF M4 AT 01/0712Z, AND ENDED AT 01/1121Z. THERE WAS NO OPTICAL CORRELATION FOR THIS EVENT. NEW REGIONS 5672 (N24E72) AND 5673 (N23E19) WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. M-FLARES AND AN ISOLATED X-FLARE ARE LIKELY TO OCCUR FROM WITHIN THE 5669/5671 COMPLEX.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 01/2100Z
sections.text: TO 02/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGIONS 5669 AND 5671 WERE COMBINED TODAY. THE RESULTANT REGION WAS NUMBER 5669 WITH A LOCATION OF S17E27 (NO FURTHER REFERENCES WILL BE MADE TO REGION 5671). THIS LARGE AND EXTREMELY COMPLEX REGION SPANS SOME 26 DEGREES IN LONGITUDE AND WAS THE SOURCE OF AN M5/2N FLARE AT 01/2359Z. MINOR DISCRETE FREQUENCY BURSTS ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. THE REGION ALSO PRODUCED THREE ADDITIONAL M-CLASS FLARES: AN M1/SF AT 02/0156Z, AN M2/1B AT 02/0623Z WITH AN ASSOCIATED 720 SFU TENFLARE, AND ANOTHER M2/1B AT 02/1140Z WITH AN ASSOCIATED 360 SFU TENFLARE. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED, WEAK TYPE II SWEEP BURST OCCURRED AT 02/1353Z. ITS VELOCITY WAS ESTIMATED TO BE LESS THAN 600 KM/SEC. NEW REGION 5674 (N22W41), A SIMPLE BIPOLE, WAS NUMBERED TODAY.

sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5669 IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE M-CLASS FLARES DURING THE PERIOD. THERE IS ALSO A FAIR CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE FROM THIS REGION.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 02/2100Z
sections.text: TO 03/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY REMAINED HIGH. REGION 5669 (S17E15) PRODUCED AN IMPULSIVE X1/1B FLARE AT 03/1432Z. A 5000 F.U. BURST AT 10CM ACCOMPANIED THIS EVENT BUT NO METER WAVELENGTH BURSTS WERE OBSERVED. REGION 5669 ALSO PRODUCED AN M4/1B AT 02/2236Z THERE WAS NO DEFINITIVE OPTICAL CORRELATION WITH AN M5 FLARE AT 03/1044Z BUT REGION 5669 WAS THE LIKELY SOURCE. THIS REGION CONTINUED TO GROW. A DRAMATIC INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF SMALL SPOTS IN REGION 5669 WAS REPORTED. INTENSE MAGNETIC GRADIENTS AND STRONG MIXING OF POLARITIES WERE EVIDENT THROUGHOUT REGION 5669. TWO SMALL REGIONS (5675 AT N20W24 AND 5676 AT N27E75) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.text: AT A HIGH LEVEL. MULTIPLE CLASS M FLARES ARE EXPECTED FROM REGION 5669. CLASS X FLARES ARE ALSO PREDICTED FROM THIS AREA DURING THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS PREDOMINANTLY UNSETTLED DURING THE PAST 24 HOURS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: FORECAST TO REACH ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS IN RESPONSE TO RECENT FLARE ACTIVITY FROM REGION 5669. INTERMITTENT MAJOR STORM LEVELS ARE POSSIBLE BUT CONTINUOUS MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE NOT PREDICTED AT THIS TIME DUE TO THE LACK OF METER WAVELENGTH BURSTS WITH RECENT ENERGETIC FLARES. THE POSSIBILITY EXISTS FOR A PROTON EVENT AND PCA FROM FUTURE FLARES IN REGION 5669.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 03/2100Z
sections.text: TO 04/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5669 (S17E02) PRODUCED AN X1/2B FLARE AT 04/0904Z FOLLOWED IMMEDIATELY BY A SEPARATE M9 BURST FROM THE SAME REGION AT 04/0919Z. THIS DOUBLE BURST WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A 470 F.U. BURST AT 10CM AND A WEAK TYPE II. REGION 5669 ALSO PRODUCED AN M1/1B AT 03/2343Z, AN M1/1N AT 04/0635Z, AND AN M1/1N AT 04/1220Z. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED M1 BURST OCCURRED AT 04/0952Z. REGION 5669 REMAINS VERY LARGE AND MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. SOME PENUMBRAL DECAY OCCURRED BUT MAGNETIC SHEAR IS EVIDENT IN THE CENTER OF THE REGION. REGION 5672 (N24E33) GREW DURING THE PERIOD AND PRODUCED AN M2/1N FLARE AT 04/1302Z. SEVERAL SMALL REGIONS EMERGED ON THE DISK.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD CONTINUE
sections.text: AT A GENERALLY HIGH LEVEL FOR THE PERIOD. CONTINUED CLASS M FLARES AND OCCASIONAL CLASS X FLARES ARE PREDICTED FROM REGION 5669. THE FREQUENCY OF THESE EVENTS MAY BEGIN TO SLOW AS THE REGION MATURES AND THEN BEGINS A DECAY PHASE. REGION 5672 CAN PRODUCE ISOLATED CLASS M FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 03/2100Z TO 04/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT GENERALLY ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. DURING A BRIEF PERIOD BETWEEN 04/0300-0430Z, MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS WERE EXPERIENCED AT HIGH LATITUDES. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 45 GAMMA WAS OBSERVED AT 04/0026Z. A WEAK PROTON EVENT BEGAN NEAR 04/0120Z AND REACHED A PEAK FLUX OF 44 P.F.U. AT 04/0510Z. THE EVENT WAS NEARLY UNDER THRESHOLD AT ISSUE TIME. A PCA BEGAN NEAR 04/0330Z (BASED UPON PROTON FLUXES) AND ENDED DURING THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE AT GENERALLY ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE ENTIRE PERIOD AS THE RESULTS OF RECENT FLARE ACTIVITY REACH THE EARTH. BRIEF PERIODS AT MAJOR STORM LEVELS CAN BE EXPECTED. THE POSSIBILITY EXISTS FOR ANOTHER PROTON EVENT AND PCA DURING THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5669 (S18W36) PRODUCED AN M1/1N AT 07/0536Z, AN M1/1B AT 07/0829Z WITH A 10CM BURST OF 290 F.U., AND AN M1/1B AT 07/1537Z. SOME OF THE TRAILER AND INTERMEDIATE SPOTS IN REGION 5669 APPEAR TO BE FRAGMENTING WHICH INDICATES THE BEGINNING OF A DECAY PHASE. HOWEVER, MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY AND STRONG GRADIENTS REMAIN. REGION 5680 (N16E52) ALSO SHOWED ITSELF AS A MODERATE SIZE CLASS E GROUP BUT ITS EVOLUTION IS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE AT THIS TIME. NEW REGION 5687 (N14E78) ROTATED OVER THE LIMB AS A SMALL TO MODERATE SIZE CLASS D GROUP. THIS REGION IS IN THE AREA WHERE OLD REGION 5643 WAS DUE TO RETURN.

sections.text: AT A MODERATE LEVEL. REGION 5669 IS STILL CAPABLE OF PRODUCING HIGH CLASS M AND CLASS X FLARES DURING ITS DECAY. THE OTHER REGIONS MENTIONED ABOVE ARE CAPABLE OF PRODUCING ISOLATED CLASS M FLARES.

sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY CONTINUES MODERATE. REGION 5669 (S18W50) GENERATED TWO M-CLASS FLARES, AN M1/0B AT 07/2117Z AND AN M1/0F AT 0409Z. A NEW REGION WAS NUMBERED IN THE SOUTHEAST, REGION 5689 (S11E73).

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 08/2100Z
sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5669 (S18W61) PRODUCED AN X1/1F TENFLARE AT 1934Z. IT WAS ALSO THE SITE OF AN M1/1N AT 08/2140Z AND AN M1/0F AT 0444Z. SLOW DECAY CONTINUES IN THE REGION. REGION 5680 (N16E26) YIELDED AN X-CLASS FLARE OF ITS OWN, AN X1/2B TENFLARE WITH TYPE II AND TYPE IV SWEEP AT 0914Z. THAT REGION HAD OTHER FLARES INCLUDING AN M1/1N WITH TYPE II AT 0523Z AND AN M1/1N AT 1854Z. REGION 5680 HAS GROWN IN BOTH WHITE LIGHT AND H-ALPHA DURING THE INTERVAL. NUMEROUS C-CLASS FLARES WERE GENERATED BY A VARIETY OF REGIONS, MOST OF WHICH ARE POSITIONED IN THE BUSY NORTHEAST QUADRANT. NEWLY ASSIGNED REGION 5690 (N21E65) IS A MATURE BUT SIMPLE SPOT GROUP.

sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. THERE IS NO REASON TO THINK THAT EITHER REGION 5669 OR 5680 WILL ABATE ITS FLARE PRODUCTION. EXPECT OCCASIONAL X-CLASS ACTIVITY FROM THOSE SITES AS WELL AS A NUMBER OF M-CLASS FLARES IN THE NEXT 24 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 10/2100Z
sections.text: TO 11/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. THE ONLY M-CLASS EVENT OF THE PERIOD WAS A RECENT M6/2B AT 1943Z FROM REGION 5680 (N17E01). A BURST OF 480 SFU AT 10 CM. AND BOTH TYPE II AND TYPE IV SWEEP ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. FREQUENT C-CLASS FLARES OCCURRED THROUGHOUT THE DAY AND THESE WERE DISTRIBUTED AMONG ELEVEN ACTIVE REGIONS. THE BIGGEST CONTRIBUTOR WAS REGION 5683 (N17W14) WHICH GREW DRAMATICALLY DURING THE INTERVAL. FREQUENT SURGING WAS REPORTED ON THE SOUTHWEST LIMB WHERE REGION 5669 (S19W82) IS NOW POSITIONED. ONE NEW REGION WAS BORN ON THE DISK, 5693 (S10E06).

sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. WATCH REGIONS 5669, 5680, AND 5683 FOR CONTINUED MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT 24 TO 36 HOURS DUE TO FLARE ACTIVITY ON 09 SEPT. ACTIVITY SHOULD THEN WEAKEN WITH UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE CONDITIONS THE RULE BY THE END OF THE INTERVAL.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 11/2100Z
sections.text: TO 12/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY REMAINS HIGH. REGION 5669, NOW AT WEST LIMB NEAR S15, PRODUCED A LONG (OVER SIX HOURS) DURATION X-RAY EVENT OF MAGNITUDE M5. IT REACHED MAXIMUM AT 0814Z. LOOPS HAVE PERSISTED AT THE SITE OF THE FLARE WHICH MAY ACCOUNT FOR THE STILL ELEVATED X-RAY BACKGROUND. THE REGION ALSO YIELDED AN M2/1N AT 11/2350Z, AND AN M3/0F AT 0519Z WHILE THE LDE WAS IN PROGRESS BEHIND THE LIMB. REGION 5686 (N16E02) HAD AN M7/2N FLARE AT 1012Z, ALSO WHILE THE LDE WAS IN PROGRESS. THE DISK HAS BEEN FAIRLY QUIET SINCE THIS RASH OF ACTIVITY EARLY IN THE DAY. MOST REGIONS WERE STABLE OR DECAYING. ONE NEW REGION, 5694 (N26E55), WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. WITH THE DEPARTURE OF REGION 5669 FROM THE DISK, FLARE PROBABILITIES WILL FALL IN KIND. THERE IS A CHANCE THAT A LARGE FLARE FROM THAT REGION COULD BE FELT NEAR EARTH IF IT OCCURS IN THE NEXT 24 HOURS. OF THE REMAINING REGIONS VISIBLE, REGIONS 5680 (N16W13), 5683 (N17W27), AND 5686 (N16E02) OFFER THE MOST PROMISE FOR M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 11/2100Z TO 12/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS GENERALLY UNSETTLED. ALTHOUGH CONDITIONS ARE MORE DISTURBED THAN YESTERDAY, ACTIVITY DID NOT REACH LEVELS PREVIOUSLY FORECAST. A VERY WEAK PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV BEGAN AT 1935Z AND THE MAXIMUM TO THIS POINT IS 13 PFU. THE LONG-DURATION X-RAY EVENT OF EARLIER TODAY IS THE MOST PROBABLE SOURCE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE AT MID-LATITUDES. MINOR STORM TO ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE ANTICIPATED AT HIGH LATITUDES. THE LONG DURATION FLARE OF EARLIER TODAY IS EXPECTED TO DISTURB THE FIELD AT THE END OF THE INTERVAL.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET TO UNSETTLED TOMORROW. MOSTLY ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE FORECAST FOR 15 SEPTEMBER IN RESPONSE TO THE LONG DURATION X-RAY EVENT THAT OCCURRED ON 12 SEPTEMBER. CONDITIONS SHOULD DECLINE TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS BY THE THIRD DAY.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS INITIALLY AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS WITH SOME PERIODS OF MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS AT HIGH LATITUDES. sections.text: TO 23/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 5694 (N26W91) PRODUCED TWO C-CLASS FLARES WHILE CROSSING THE WEST LIMB. sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 27/2100Z
sections.text: TO 28/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5712 (S18E55) PRODUCED AN M1/SN AT 27/2359Z AND AN M3/1B AT 28/1348Z. NEITHER FLARE PRODUCED SIGNIFICANT RADIO BURSTS AND THE LATTER FLARE WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A BRIGHT SURGE EXTENDING OVER THE SOUTHEAST LIMB TO 0.28 RADIUS. REGION 5712 APPEARS TO BE AN EXTENDED CLASS F GROUP WITH MUCH LESS AREAL COVERAGE WHEN COMPARED TO LAST ROTATION. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED M2 FLARE OCCURRED AT 28/0926Z. REGION 5698 (S26W92) IS MAKING ITS LIMB TRANSIT IN A NON-ENERGETIC MANNER. IT DID PRODUCE A BRIGHT SURGE TO .16R BETWEEN 28/1255-1414Z WITH LITTLE X-RAY ENHANCEMENT. SMALL REGIONS 5713 (N23E32) AND 5714 (N29E76) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 28/2100Z
sections.text: TO 29/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5698 (S26W105) PRODUCED A POWERFUL X9 FLARE AT 29/1133Z. A LOOP PROMINENCE SYSTEM WAS OBSERVED TO ARISE FROM THE FLARE SITE OVER THE LIMB. THIS 4 HOUR LONG FLARE ALSO PRODUCED A MODERATE INTENSITY TYPE IV BURST, AND AT 10CM, A BURST OF 6800 F.U. WAS OBSERVED. REGION 5698 ALSO PRODUCED A NON-ENERGETIC BRIGHT SURGE TO 0.5R BETWEEN 29/0528-0648Z. REGION 5712 (S18E45) REMAINED STABLE AND PRODUCED A FEW CLASS C FLARES. THIS REGION DISPLAYED SOME MINOR MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY AND WAS STABLE.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BECOME
sections.text: MODERATE. REGION 5698 WILL BE OCCULTED BY THE WEST LIMB SUFFICIENTLY THAT A REPEAT OF THE FLARE TODAY WOULD RESULT IN ONLY A MID CLASS M FLARE. REGION 5712 APPEARS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING A CLASS M FLARE EVERY ONE TO TWO DAYS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 28/2100Z TO 29/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS PREDOMINANTLY QUIET DURING THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE GEOPHYSICAL EVENT OF NOTE IS THE PROTON EVENT FROM THE X9 FLARE. THE GT 10MEV FLUXES PASSED THRESHOLD AT 29/1205Z. AT 29/2100Z, THE GT 10 MEV FLUX WAS AT 3100 P.F.U. THE GT 100 MEV FLUX PASSED ITS EVENT THRESHOLD AT 29/1320Z AND A MAXIMUM OF 310 P.F.U. OCCURRED AT 29/1955Z. A PCA BEGAN NEAR 29/1158Z AND A MAXIMUM OF APPROXIMATELY 16 DB ABSORPTION OCCURRED NEAR 29/2100Z. NEUTRON MONITORS RECORDED A 500 PERCENT INCREASE OVER BACKGROUND, MAKING THIS A MAJOR GROUND LEVEL EVENT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE FOR 30 SEP-01 OCT DUE TO A FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE ON 26-27 SEP. MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE FORECAST FOR 02 OCT IN RESPONSE TO THE X9 FLARE OBSERVED TODAY. IN THE ABSENCE OF FURTHER FLARES FROM REGION 5698 BEHIND THE LIMB, THE MAJOR PROTON EVENT AND PCA IN PROGRESS SHOULD DECAY SLOWLY DURING THE NEXT THREE DAYS TO NEAR BACKGROUND LEVELS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 29/2100Z
sections.text: TO 30/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5712 (S18E29) PRODUCED AN M2/2N FLARE AT 30/0259Z WITH A MINOR 10CM BURST OF 66 FLUX UNITS. THIS REGION GREW SLOWLY AND SOME PROPER MOTION OF AN INTERIOR ISOLATED POLE WAS OBSERVED. REGION 5714 (N27E59) MAY CONSIST OF TWO STACKED REGIONS. HOWEVER, THEIR SHARED NEUTRAL LINE AND THE H-ALPHA PLAGE STRUCTURE ARGUE FOR ONE COMPLEX. THE WEST LIMB NEAR S26 WAS QUIET WHERE REGION 5698 ROTATED OVER.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD CONTINUE
sections.text: AT A MODERATE LEVEL. REGION 5712 IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING ONE OR MORE CLASS M FLARES PER DAY. AN ISOLATED MAJOR FLARE IS POSSIBLE FROM THIS AREA. OLD REGION 5697 (N28, L-352) WILL RETURN TO THE EAST LIMB ON 02 OCT. LAST ROTATION THIS REGION GREW RAPIDLY PRIOR TO WEST LIMB TRANSIT AND MAY INCREASE ACTIVITY LEVELS UPON ITS RETURN.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 29/2100Z TO 30/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS MOSTLY QUIET FOR THE EARLY PART OF THE PERIOD AND BECAME SLIGHTLY ACTIVE AFTER A SMALL SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 8 GAMMA WAS OBSERVED AT 30/1715Z. THE MAJOR PROTON EVENT WHICH BEGAN AT 29/1210Z (ENERGIES GT 10MEV) REACHED A MAXIMUM FLUX OF 4500 P.F.U. AT 30/0210Z. THE GREATER THAN 100MEV FLUX WHICH EXCEEDED 100 P.F.U. AT 29/1320Z REACHED MAXIMUM OF 310 P.F.U. AT 29/2000Z AND DECAYED BELOW 100 P.F.U. AT 30/1035Z. AT 30/2100Z THE GT 10MEV FLUX WAS 2600 P.F.U. AND THE GT 100MEV FLUX WAS 34 P.F.U.  THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT CONTINUES. RECORDS INDICATE THAT THIS PROTON EVENT PRODUCED THE HIGHEST INTENSITY GROUND LEVEL EVENT IN OVER 30 YEARS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD CONTINUE SLIGHTLY ACTIVE FOR 01 OCT. MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED FOR 02-03 OCT AS A RESULT OF THE X9 FLARE ON 29 SEP. THE GT 10 MEV PROTON EVENT AND PCA SHOULD CONTINUE TO SLOWLY DECAY DURING THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 30/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE PERIOD WAS AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED C6 AT 01/0036Z. REGION 5712 (S18E16) PRODUCED TWO SMALL CLASS C FLARES. THIS REGION APPEARED TO STABLILIZE AS A SMALL EXTENDED CLASS F GROUP WHICH IS TRAILER DOMINANT IN WHITE LIGHT. REGION 5719 (N25E51) WAS SPLIT OFF FROM REGION 5714 (N29E40). NEW REGIONS 5720 (S09E02) AND 5721 (N29E82) WERE NUMBERED. REGION 5721 WAS REPORTED AS A SMALL SPOT COMING OVER THE LIMB BUT THERE MAY BE A LARGER REGION BEHIND THIS SPOT.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BE LOW
sections.text: TO MODERATE. AN ISOLATED CLASS M FLARE IS POSSIBLE FROM REGION 5712. IF NEW REGION 5721 IS THE RETURN OF OLD REGION 5697 AND GROWTH CONTINUED ON THE INVISIBLE HEMISPHERE, IT IS ALSO POSSIBLE ACTIVITY LEVELS COULD BECOME ELEVATED DUE TO THIS AREA.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 30/2100Z TO 01/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS PREDOMINANTLY ACTIVE DURING THE LAST 24 HOURS. THE GREATER THAN 10MEV FLUX BEGAN THE PERIOD AT 2600 P.F.U. AND THE GREATER THAN 100MEV FLUX WAS AT 34 P.F.U. AT THAT TIME. BY 01/2100Z THE PARTICLE FLUX HAD DECAYED TO 85 P.F.U. AT GT 10MEV, AND WAS NEAR BACKGROUND AT GT 100MEV. THE PCA REMAINED IN PROGRESS BUT DECAYED TO NEAR NON-EVENT LEVEL.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR 02-03 OCT IN RESPONSE TO THE X9 FLARE FROM THE WEST LIMB AT 29/1133Z. SLIGHTLY ACTIVE CONDITIONS SHOULD BE EXPERIENCED ON 04 OCT. THE GT 10MEV FLUX SHOULD CONTINUE TO DECAY SLOWLY DURING THE NEXT TWO DAYS. THIS EVENT SHOULD END SOMETIME ON 03 OCT.

sections.text: PREDOMINANTLY LOW. REGION 5712 HAS THE CAPABILITY OF PRODUCING ISOLATED CLASS M FLARES DURING THE PERIOD. REGIONS NEAR THE EAST LIMB MAY ALSO BE CAPABLE OF ISOLATED CLASS M FLARE PRODUCTION BUT CONFIDENT PREDICTIONS MUST AWAIT LESS FORESHORTENED OBSERVATIONS.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED DURING THE PERIOD. THE MAGNETIC DISTURBANCE EXPECTED FROM THE X9 FLARE ON 29 SEP FAILED TO MATERIALIZE. THE PROTON EVENT REMAINED IN PROGRESS. THE GREATER THAN 10MEV FLUX WAS 85 P.F.U. AT 01/2100Z AND DECAYED SLOWLY TO 37 P.F.U. AT 02/2100Z. sections.text: SHOULD BE GENERALLY UNSETTLED FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS. ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE FORECAST FOR HIGH LATITUDES ON 05 OCT. THE PROTON EVENT SHOULD CONTINUE TO DECAY, ENDING ON 03-04 OCT.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 17/2100Z
sections.text: TO 18/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5747 (S27E16) PRODUCED AN M7/2B FLARE AT 18/1823Z. THE MINOR DISCRETE RADIO BURSTS ACCOMPANYING THIS FLARE INCLUDED A 310 SFU TENFLARE. THIS REGION REMAINED LARGE AND MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX BOTH BEFORE AND IN THE WAKE OF THE MAJOR FLARE. REGION 5744 (S23W03) PRODUCED SEVERAL SUBFLARES WHILE THE REMAINING REGIONS WERE STABLE THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MOSTLY MODERATE. REGION 5747 APPEARS TO BE THE ONLY REGION CAPABLE OF M-CLASS ACTIVITY. THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR AN X-CLASS FLARE FROM THIS REGION.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 17/2100Z TO 18/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS AT MIDDLE LATITUDES. THE HIGHER LATITUDE FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 21 GAMMAS (NANOTESLAS) WAS OBSERVED AT BOULDER AT 18/0051Z. THE DISTURBANCE MAY HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY THE DISAPPEARANCE OF A 30 DEGREE FILAMENT AT 14/2327-2352Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED AT MIDDLE LATITUDES. THE HIGHER LATITUDE FIELD IS EXPECTED TO BE AT UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS. NO SIGNIFICANT GEOMAGNETIC EFFECTS ARE EXPECTED IN THE WAKE OF TODAY'S MAJOR FLARE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 18/2100Z
sections.text: TO 19/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5747 (S26E01) PRODUCED AN X13/4B FLARE AT 19/1258Z (X13 IS ESTIMATED DUE TO SENSOR SATURATION). MAJOR TYPES II AND IV SWEEPS, MAJOR DISCRETE RADIO BURSTS, AND FLARE LOOPS ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. SUNSPOT REPORTS INDICATE THE REGION RETAINED ITS HIGH DEGREE OF COMPLEXITY AFTER THE FLARE. THE FLARE REMAINED IN PROGRESS AT THE END OF THE SUMMARY PERIOD. MOST REMAINING REGIONS WERE QUIET AND STABLE. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5747 IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING BOTH M- AND X-CLASS FLARES DURING THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 18/2100Z TO 19/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS AT MIDDLE LATITUDES. THE HIGH LATITUDE FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. A SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV BEGAN AT 19/1305Z. THE MAXIMUM GREATER THAN 10 MEV FLUX OBSERVED THUS FAR WAS 2700 PFU AT 19/1935Z. A SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 100 MEV BEGAN AT 19/1710Z. ITS MAXIMUM THUS FAR HAS BEEN 190 PFU AT 19/2040Z. BOTH EVENTS REMAINED IN PROGRESS AT THE END OF THE SUMMARY PERIOD. THESE EVENTS WERE PRODUCED BY TODAY'S MAJOR FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE FIRST TWO DAYS OF THE PERIOD IN THE WAKE OF TODAY'S MAJOR FLARE. CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO SUBSIDE TO ACTIVE LEVELS DURING THE FINAL DAY OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 19/2100Z
sections.text: TO 20/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5747 (S26W12) DISPLAYED SLIGHT DECAY BUT REMAINED VERY LARGE AND COMPLEX. IT PRODUCED TWO M-CLASS FLARES DURING THE PERIOD. THE FIRST WAS AN M1/SN AT 20/0341Z AND THE SECOND WAS AN M1/1B AT 20/1512Z. NO SIGNIFICANT RADIO EMISSIONS WERE ASSOCIATED WITH EITHER OF THESE FLARES. THE REMAINING REGIONS WERE EITHER STABLE OR DECLINING. NEW REGIONS 5754 (S20E66) AND 5755 (S15W24) WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5747 IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING M-CLASS FLARES. AN X-CLASS FLARE MAY ALSO OCCUR FROM THIS REGION. NEW REGION 5754 PROVIDES A VERY SLIGHT CHANCE FOR A M-FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 19/2100Z TO 20/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE DISTURBANCE BEGAN SOMETIME BETWEEN 20/0900-1200Z (NO SUDDEN STORM COMMENCEMENT WAS OBSERVED). THE STORM WAS A RESULT OF THE X13/4B FLARE THAT OCCURRED YESTERDAY. THE SATELLITE PROTON EVENT THAT BEGAN YESTERDAY REMAINED IN PROGRESS. THE MAXIMUM GREATER THAN 10 MEV FLUX WAS 73000 PFU AT 20/1530Z. THE MAXIMUM GREATER THAN 100 MEV FLUX WAS 680 PFU AT 20/1530Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MAJOR TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS TOMORROW. MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS ARE POSSIBLE AT HIGHER LATITUDES FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD WHILE THE MIDDLE AND LOWER LATITUDES ARE EXPECTED TO BE AT MOSTLY ACTIVE LEVELS. THE PROTON EVENT IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 20/2100Z
sections.text: TO 21/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 5747 (S27W24) PRODUCED THREE M-CLASS EVENTS DURING THE PERIOD. IT'S LARGEST EVENT OF THE PERIOD WAS AN M2/1N FLARE AT 21/0156Z WHICH WAS ACCOMPANIED BY MINOR DISCRETE RADIO EMISSIONS. SPLITTING OF THE REGION'S LARGE ASSYMETRIC MAIN SPOT WAS EVIDENT, BUT NO CLEAR INDICATION OF DECAY EXISTED. THE GROUP REMAINED LARGE AND MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. REGION 5754 (S19E57) CONTINUED IT'S GROWTH PHASE AND PRODUCED ELEVEN FLARES THE LARGEST OF WHICH WAS A C2/1F AT 21/0556Z. NEW REGIONS 5756 (N11E59), 5757 (N25E25), AND 5758 (S12E67) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5747 IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE M-CLASS FLARES. AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE IS POSSIBLE FROM THIS REGION. REGION 5754 MAY PRODUCE AN ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 20/2100Z TO 21/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT ACTIVE TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON EVENT WHICH COMMENCED AT 19/1305Z CONTINUED. THE GREATER THAN 100 MEV PROTON EVENT ENDED AT 20/2200Z. ALL OF THE ABOVE EFFECTS OCCURRED IN THE WAKE OF THE X13/4B FLARE OF 19 OCT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE AT MIDDLE LATITUDES AND AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS AT HIGHER LATITUDES DURING THE FIRST DAY OF THE FORECAST PERIOD. THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD SHOULD SEE THE FIELD AT UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS AS FLARE EFFECTS SUBSIDE. THE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 21/2100Z
sections.text: TO 22/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5747 (S26W36) PRODUCED AN X2/2B FLARE AT 22/1805Z. THE EVENT WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A 22000 SFU TENFLARE (ALONG WITH OTHER MAJOR DISCRETE BURSTS ACROSS THE SPECTRUM) AND MAJOR TYPES II AND IV SWEEP BURSTS. SUNSPOT OBSERVATIONS RECEIVED IN THE WAKE OF THE X-FLARE INDICATED THE REGION DID NOT DECREASE IN SIZE OR COMPLEXITY. THE REGION PRODUCED OCCASIONAL M-CLASS FLARES PRIOR TO THE X2. REGION 5750 (N12W76), FORMERLY A PLAGE REGION, REEMERGED AS A B-TYPE GROUP EARLY IN THE PERIOD AND PRODUCED OCCASIONAL SUBFLARES. NEW REGION 5759 (S13E07) WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5747 REMAINS CAPABLE OF M-CLASS AND ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE PRODUCTION. REGIONS 5750 AND 5754 (S20E45) ARE LIKELY TO PRODUCE C-CLASS FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 21/2100Z TO 22/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MOSTLY MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV CONTINUED. HOWEVER, AN INCREASE IN THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV FLUX OCCURRED NEAR 1810Z AS A RESULT OF THE X2/2B FLARE. THE MAXIMUM FLUX SINCE THE INCREASE WAS 2800 PFU AT 22/2100Z. A SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 100 MEV BEGAN IN THE WAKE OF TODAY'S MAJOR FLARE. IT BEGAN AT 22/1830Z AND REACHED A MAXIMUM OF 230 PFU AT 22/1855Z. THIS EVENT REMAINED IN PROGRESS AT THE END OF THE SUMMARY PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE UNTIL LATE TOMORROW. THERERAFTER, THE FIELD IS EXPECTED TO BE AT MOSTLY MAJOR STORM LEVELS IN RESPONSE TO TODAY'S X-FLARE. THE SATELLITE PROTON EVENTS AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV AND GREATER THAN 100 MEV ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 22/2100Z
sections.text: TO 23/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY REMAINED HIGH. REGION 5747 (S26W48) PRODUCED AN X1/2B FLARE AT 23/1243Z. NO SWEEP EVENTS WERE SEEN WITH THIS FLARE AND DISCRETE FREQUENCY RADIO BURSTS WERE ONLY MODERATE AND RESTRICTED TO HIGH FREQUENCIES ONLY. REGION 5747 ALSO PRODUCED M1/SF FLARES AT 23/0425Z AND 23/0651Z. THIS REGION EXHIBITED GROWTH DURING THE PERIOD. REGION 5748 (S16W50) GREW RAPIDLY DURING THE PERIOD AND IS NOW A MODERATE SIZE CLASS E SUNSPOT GROUP. NEW REGION 5760 (N11E13) EMERGED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD REMAIN
sections.text: HIGH FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS. REGION 5747 HAS SHOWN ITS CAPABILITY AS A MAJOR FLARE PRODUCER AND ADDITIONAL GROWTH SHOULD INCREASE THE PRODUCTION OF LARGE CLASS M AND CLASS X FLARES. REGION 5748 SHOULD BEGIN TO PRODUCE LOW LEVEL CLASS M FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 22/2100Z TO 23/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE FIRST HALF OF THE PERIOD. GENERALLY UNSETTLED CONDITIONS WERE EXPERIENCED DURING THE LATTER HALF. THE SATELLITE PROTON EVENT CONTINUED. GREATER THAN 10MEV FLUX AT 22/2100Z WAS 2800 P.F.U., ROSE TO 8300 P.F.U. AT 23/0710Z, AND ENDED THE PERIOD AT 3000 P.F.U.  THE GREATER THAN 100MEV FLUX BEGAN THE PERIOD AT NEAR 160 P.F.U. AND DECAYED TO 30 P.F.U. AT 23/2100Z. THE PCA CONTINUED IN PROGRESS. NOTE: RECALIBRATION OF THE GOES PARTICLE CHANNELS IS UNDERWAY. RECENTLY REPORTED PROTON FLUXES MAY BE CLOSE TO A FACTOR OF 2 TOO HIGH.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: FORECAST TO BE AT MAJOR STORM LEVELS ON 24 OCT AS A RESULT OF THE X2 FLARE ON 22 OCT. MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE ON 25 OCT WITH ACTIVE LEVELS FORECAST FOR 26 OCT. THE GREATER THAN 10MEV PROTON EVENT IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE FOR SEVERAL DAYS. ADDITIONAL MAJOR FLARES FROM REGION 5747 COULD INCREASE THE SEVERITY OF THE PROTON EVENT AND ACCOMPANYING POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 23/2100Z
sections.text: TO 24/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY RETURNED TO HIGH LEVELS. REGION 5747 (S27W60) PRODUCED A LONG LIVED X5/3B FLARE WHICH REACHED MAXIMUM AT 24/1831Z. STRONG TYPE II AND IV SWEEPS WERE OBSERVED AS WAS A BURST OF 9800 FLUX UNITS AT 10CM. AN M6 PRECURSOR BURST STARTED AT 25/1736Z THEN THE FLARE SPREAD IN AREA AND INCREASED IN INTENSITY. FORESHORTENING LIMITED ANALYSIS OF THIS MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX REGION. REGION 5748 (S16W62) CONTINUED TO GROW AND PRODUCED SEVERAL SUBFLARES. SMALL NEW REGION 5761 (S12E58) WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BE
sections.text: PREDOMINANTLY HIGH FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS. REGION 5747 SHOULD CONTINUE TO PRODUCE CLASS M AND CLASS X FLARES. REGION 5748 IS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING LOW CLASS M FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 23/2100Z TO 24/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS PRIMARILY UNSETTLED UNTIL A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 24 GAMMA WAS OBSERVED AT 24/1856Z. THIS SHOCK IS ATTRIBUTED TO THE X2 FLARE ON 22/1805Z. THE PROTON EVENT AT ENERGIES GT 10MEV CONTINUED. THE GT 10MEV FLUX BEGAN THE PERIOD AT 3000 P.F.U. AND DECAYED TO APPROXIMATELY 350 P.F.U. AT 24/1830Z. AS A RESULT OF THE X5 FLARE, FLUXES BEGAN TO RISE AFTER THAT TIME REACHING 2300 P.F.U. AT THE END OF THE PERIOD. THE GT 100MEV FLUX ALSO BEGAN TO RISE FOLLOWING THE X5 FLARE AND AT 24/2100Z THE FLUX WAS NEARING THE 100 P.F.U. THRESHOLD. A GROUND LEVEL EVENT OF 80 PERCENT OVER BACKGROUND WAS OBSERVED. THE PCA CONTINUED AND INTENSIFIED FOLLOWING THE FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR 25 OCT FOLLOWING THE SUDDEN IMPULSE MENTIONED ABOVE. CONDITIONS SHOULD CALM SLIGHTLY TO ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM ON 26 OCT. THE FIELD SHOULD AGAIN GO INTO MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS ON 27 OCT IN RESPONSE TO THE X5 FLARE AT 24/1831Z. THE GT 100MEV PROTON EVENT SHOULD CONTINUE THROUGH 25 OCT. THE GT 10MEV EVENT AND PCA SHOULD CONTINUE THROUGH THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 24/2100Z
sections.text: TO 25/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY REMAINED HIGH. REGION 5747 (S27W73) PRODUCED AN M8/2N FLARE AT 25/1639Z. NO TYPE II OR IV BURSTS WERE OBSERVED AND MODERATE TO MAJOR DISCRETE RADIO BURSTS WERE OBSERVED ONLY AT 4995MHZ AND ABOVE. REGION 5747 ALSO PRODUCED A SHORT DURATION M1/1F AT 25/0500Z. THIS REGION IS TOO NEAR THE LIMB FOR MEANINGFUL ANALYSIS OR DETERMINATION OF TRENDS. SUBFLARES WERE PRODUCED BY SEVERAL OF THE OTHER DISK REGIONS.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD CONTINUE
sections.text: PREDOMINANTLY HIGH FOR THE PERIOD. REGION 5747 WILL MAKE ITS WEST LIMB TRANSIT ON 28 OCT. HOWEVER, MAJOR FLARES WILL CONTINUE TO BE VISIBLE IN X-RAYS FOR 29-30 OCT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 24/2100Z TO 25/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS ACTIVE AT THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD. MINOR STORM LEVELS WERE EXPERIENCED (MAINLY AT HIGH LATITUDES) DURING THE 25/0300-1200Z INTERVAL. NEAR QUIET GEOMAGNETIC CONDITIONS WERE OBSERVED FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. THE GT 10MEV FLUX BEGAN THE PERIOD AT 2200 P.F.U., REACHED A MAXIMUM OF 4100 P.F.U. AT 25/0210Z, AND DECAYED TO 1400 P.F.U. BY 25/2100Z. THE GT 100MEV FLUX PEAKED AT 130 P.F.U. NEAR 25/0015Z AND DROPPED BELOW THE 100 P.F.U. LEVEL AT 25/0335Z. THE PCA REMAINED IN PROGRESS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: IS FORECAST TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE ON 26 OCT. ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED ON 27-28 OCT IN RESPONSE TO THE X5 FLARE ON 24 OCT. HIGH LATITUDE STATIONS MAY EXPERIENCE MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS DURING THE 27-28 OCT INTERVAL. THE GT 10MEV PROTON EVENT AND PCA ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 25/2100Z
sections.text: TO 26/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5747 (S30W84) PRODUCED A VERY IMPULIVE M8/SF AT 26/2048Z. A 10CM BURST OF 870 FLUX UNITS ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE AS DID MAJOR BURSTS AT HIGHER WAVELENGTHS. REGION 5747 WAS NEARLY QUIET DURING THE PERIOD PRIOR TO THIS EVENT. SMALL NEW REGIONS 5763 (N22E34) AND 5764 (N25E83) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BE
sections.text: PREDOMINANTLY MODERATE FOR 27-28 OCT WITH A CHANCE OF AN ISOLATED CLASS X FLARE FROM DEPARTING REGION 5747. X-RAY BURST ACTIVITY SHOULD DECREASE BEGINNING ON 29 OCT AS REGION 5747 ROTATES COMPLETELY FROM VIEW.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 25/2100Z TO 26/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE DURING THE FIRST HALF OF THE PERIOD. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 14 GAMMA WAS OBSERVED IN BOULDER AT 26/1428Z. ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS WERE EXPERIENCED FOLLOWING THE SHOCK. THIS DISTURBANCE IS ATTRIBUTED TO THE X5 FLARE ON 24 OCT. THE GT 10MEV PROTON EVENT AND PCA REMAINED IN PROGRESS. THE GT 10MEV FLUX AT 25/2100Z WAS 1400 P.F.U. AND DECAYED SMOOTHLY TO 330 P.F.U. AT THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE MID LATITUDE
sections.text: GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS FORECAST TO BE ACTIVE FOR 27-28 OCT CALMING TO UNSETTLED ON 29 OCT. AT HIGH LATITUDES, MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED FOR 27-28 OCT ALSO CALMING TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS ON 29 OCT. THE GT 10MEV PROTON EVENT AND PCA ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE THROUGH 27 OCT.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 26/2100Z
sections.text: TO 27/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY REMAINED HIGH. REGION 5747 (S30W98) PRODUCED AN X1/1N AT 27/1904Z WITH A 10CM BURST OF 1100 FLUX UNITS. THIS REGION ALSO PRODUCED AN M6/SF AT 27/1135Z WITH A 1000 FLUX UNIT BURST AT 10CM. A VERY LARGE AND DENSE BRIGHT SURGE TO 0.56R ABOVE THE LIMB WAS OBSERVED FROM THE AREA OF DEPARTED REGION 5748 (S18W96) AND WAS ASSOCIATED WITH AN M4 X-RAY BURST AT 26/2341Z. THIS EVENT ALSO PRODUCED MODERATE INTENSITY TYPE II AND WEAK TYPE IV BURSTS. ACTIVE SURGING AND ELEVATED PROMINENCE MATERIAL CONTINUED THROUGH THE PERIOD ABOVE THE LIMB WHERE REGION 5747 MADE WEST LIMB TRANSIT. SMALL REGIONS 5765 (S25E12) AND 5766 (S29E45) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY SHOULD BE MODERATE
sections.text: FOR 28 OCT WITH REGION 5747 BEING THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF CLASS M FLARES. AN ISOLATED X FLARE FROM BEYOND THE SOUTHWEST LIMB IS ALSO POSSIBLE. COMPLETE LIMB OCCULTATION OF THIS REGION SHOULD REDUCE THE OBSERVED FLARE INTENSITIES TO THE LOW RANGE FOR 29-30 OCT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 26/2100Z TO 27/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS UNSETTLED TO SLIGHTLY ACTIVE DURING THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE PROTON EVENT AND PCA CONTINUED DURING THE PERIOD BUT WEAKENED. THE GT 10MEV FLUX AT 26/2100Z WAS 330 P.F.U. AND DECAYED SMOOTHLY TO 55 P.F.U. AT 27/2100Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD
sections.text: SHOULD BE UNSETTLED TO SLIGHTLY ACTIVE FOR THE DURATION OF THE FORECAST PERIOD. IN THE ABSENCE OF ANOTHER PROTON FLARE FROM BEHIND THE SOUTHWEST LIMB, THE PCA AND PROTON EVENT SHOULD DECAY TO NEAR BACKGROUND LEVELS ON 28 OCT.

sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH.  TWO MAJOR FLARES WERE PRODUCED SINCE YESTERDAY, AN M6/2B AT 07/0323Z IN REGION 5776 (N17W00), AND AN M8/2B AT 07/2042Z IN REGION 5786 (N13E66). sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 07/2100Z
sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH.  REGION 5769 (N26W58) PRODUCED THE LARGEST FLARE OF THE PAST DAY, AN M9/2B AT 08/1912Z AND WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 10.7 CM RADIO BURST OF 819 FLUX UNITS.  THIS FLARE OCCURRED DURING AN M2/1N FLARE IN THE AREA SURROUNDING REGIONS 5781 (N12W04) AND 5783 (N19E16). REGION 5769 ALSO PRODUCED AN M1/1F AT 08/0755Z.  REGION 5776 N17W12) CONTINUES TO DECAY AND GENERATED AN M3/2N AT 08/0609Z.  GROWTH CONTINUED IN THE AREA NEAR REGION 5784 (N23E36).  MAGNETIC ANALYSIS INDICATES THAT THIS AREA IS A SINGLE, ELONGATED, BIPOLAR GROUP.  REGION 5783 HAS STARTED TO DECAY AND HAS PRODUCED SEVERAL C-CLASS FLARES IN ADDITION TO THE M-FLARE MENTIONED ABOVE.  REGION 5786 (N11E51) HAS SOME MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY, BUT HAS BEEN FAIRLY QUIET SINCE ITS M8/2B FLARE YESTERDAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: HIGH.  HIGH LEVEL M-CLASS FLARES, AND POSSIBLY X-CLASS, ARE EXPECTED.  REGIONS 5769, 5776, 5783, AND 5786 ARE POSSIBLE CANDIDATES FOR ENERGETIC ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 07/2100Z TO 08/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO ACTIVE.  A SUDDEN IMPULSE WAS OBSERVED AT 08/1122Z (36 NANOTESLA AT BOULDER).  THE PRECISE SOURCE OF THIS ACTIVITY IS UNKNOWN.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MOSTLY ACTIVE TO STORM LEVELS AS A RESULT OF THE PAST FEW DAYS OF SOLAR ACTIVITY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 08/2100Z
sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH.  EIGHT M-CLASS FLARES WERE OBSERVED SINCE YESTERDAY.  TWO OF THESE REACHED M4 (AT 09/1458Z AND 09/1939Z) AND WERE BOTH LOCATED IN REGION 5783 (N19E01).  THE FLARE AT 09/1939Z IN REGION 5783 OVERLAPPED WITH AN M1/1N FLARE, WHICH REACHED A MAXIMUM AT 09/1905Z, IN REGION 5786 (N12E42).  REGION 5783 HAS UNDERGONE SIGNIFICANT PENUMBRAL GROWTH IN THE LEADER SUNSPOTS SINCE YESTERDAY AND APPEARS TO CONTAIN A DELTA CONFIGURATION.  REGION 5786 HAS GROWN SLIGHTLY SINCE YESTERDAY AND ALSO MAY CONTAIN A DELTA IN THE TRAILER SPOT COMPLEX.  PLAGE IS ROTATING INTO VIEW AT SE20, NEAR THE EXPECTED LOCATION OF OLD RETURNING REGIONS 5747 (S26 L-212) AND 5748 (S17 L-210), HOWEVER SIGNIFICANT LIMB ACTIVITY HAS NOT YET BEEN OBSERVED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: HIGH.  ADDITIONAL HIGH LEVEL M-CLASS FLARES ARE EXPECTED. REGIONS 5783 AND 5786 ARE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES OF THIS ACTIVITY.  INITIAL OBSERVATIONS INDICATE THAT OLD REGIONS 5747 AND 5748 ARE NOT RETURNING AS ACTIVE AS WHEN THEY DEPARTED THE DISK.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 08/2100Z TO 09/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO ACTIVE.  A GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON EVENT WAS OBSERVED, AT SATELLITE ALTITUDES, TO BEGIN AT 09/0240Z, REACH A MAXIMUM OF 43 PFU AT 09/0610Z, AND END AT 09/1255Z.  THIS EVENT IS BELIEVED TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH YESTERDAY'S M9 FLARE IN REGION 5769 (N26W71).

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO STORM LEVELS FOR 10 NOVEMBER AND UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THEREAFTER.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 09/2100Z
sections.text: TO 10/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH.  SEVERAL M-CLASS FLARES WERE OBSERVED SINCE YESTERDAY.  THE LARGEST WAS AN M5/2B AT 10/1653Z IN REGION 5769 (N24W87).  THIS REGION CONTINUES TO DECAY AS IT APPROACHES THE WEST LIMB.  REGION 5783 (N18W13) CONTRIBUTED TO AT LEAST FOUR M-CLASS FLARES, THE LARGEST OF WHICH WAS AN M3/1N AT 10/0155Z.  THIS REGION CONTINUES TO GROW AND IS NOW A LARGE, COMPACT SUNSPOT GROUP WITH SIGNIFICANT MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY.  NEW REGION 5788 (S23E69) PRODUCED AN M2/2B FLARE AT 10/1948Z.  THIS REGION IS THE RETURN OF OLD REGIONS 5747 AND 5748.  SEVERAL SMALL SPOTS ARE VISIBLE IN THIS AREA AND MOST LIKELY CONSTITUTE MORE THAN ONE SEPARATE ACTIVE REGION.  CONSEQUENTLY, THIS AREA MAY BE RENUMBERED AFTER ALL OF THE SPOTS ROTATE INTO VIEW.  NEW REGION 5787 (S16W24) WAS ALSO NUMBERED.

sections.text: HIGH.  HIGH LEVEL M-CLASS FLARES ARE EXPECTED.  X-CLASS FLARES ARE POSSIBLE.  REGIONS 5783, 5786, AND 5788 ARE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES OF THIS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 11/2100Z
sections.text: TO 12/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED X1 FLARE OCCURRED AT 12/0905Z. THE FLARE WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 360 SFU TENFLARE,  A 17000 SFU BURST AT 245 MHZ, AND A MAJOR TYPE II RADIO SWEEP. REGION 5783 (N18W39) SHOWED NO SIGNS OF DECAY DURING THE PERIOD (CONTRARY TO YESTERDAY'S OBSERVATIONS) AND REMAINED MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX. REGION 5786 (N12E05) PRODUCED AN M2/2B FLARE AT 12/0916Z ACCOMPANIED BY MODEST DISCRETE FREQUENCY BURSTS. THIS REGION GREW SLIGHTLY DURING THE PERIOD. IT REMAINS UNCLEAR WHETHER REGION 5788 (S23E45) CAN BE SPLIT INTO TWO REGIONS DUE TO ITS LIMB PROXIMITY (WHICH COMPLICATES MAGNETIC ANALYSIS). REGION 5781 (N12W60) GREW SLIGHTLY. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGIONS 5783 AND 5788 ARE THE PRIMARY THREATS FOR M-FLARE PRODUCTION FOLLOWED BY 5786 AND 5781. REGION 5783 IS CAPABLE OF ISOLATED MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED. TODAY'S X1 FLARE IS NOT EXPECTED TO SIGNIFICANTLY AFFECT THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD.

sections.text: TO 13/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. AN OPTICALLY UNCORRELATED M1 X-RAY BURST OCCURRED AT 13/2017Z. NO RADIO EMISSIONS WERE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS EVENT. REGION 5783 (N18W52) SHOWED SIGNS OF GRADUAL DECAY WHILE PRODUCING SEVERAL SUBFLARES, THE LARGEST OF WHICH WAS A C2/SF AT 13/0846Z. MODEST DISCRETE RADIO EMISSIONS ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. NO SIGNIFICANT GROWTH OR DECAY WAS NOTED IN THE REMAINING REGIONS. NEW REGION 5789 (N35E23) WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 5783 PROVIDES A GOOD CHANCE FOR M-CLASS ACTIVITY AND A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE. REGIONS 5781 (N12W72), 5786 (N13W09), AND 5788 (S23E31) APPEAR CAPABLE OF ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 12/2100Z TO 13/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. A GRADUAL STORM COMMENCEMENT BEGAN NEAR 13/0300Z. MAJOR STORM PERIODS OCCURRED NEAR 13/0600Z AND 13/1500-1800Z. THE CAUSE OF THE STORMING IS UNCLEAR AT THIS TIME.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS. BRIEF PERIODS OF MINOR STORMING MAY OCCUR DURING THE FIRST HALF OF DAY ONE AND DURING THE FINAL DAY OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.text: TO 14/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. FIVE C-CLASS SUBFLARES OCCURRED. REGION 5786 (N13W23) DISPLAYED STRONG PENUMBRAL GROWTH WITHIN ITS INTERMEDIATE SPOTS. A DELTA MAGNETIC CONFIGURATION ALSO DEVELOPED WITHIN THE SAME AREA. IN CONTRAST, REGION 5783 (N18W65) CONTINUED TO GRADUALLY DECAY. THE REMAINING REGIONS WERE STABLE. NEW REGIONS 5790 (N25E12) AND 5791 (N29E76) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGIONS 5786 AND 5783 ARE THE PRIME THREATS FOR M-CLASS FLARE PRODUCTION. REGION 5786 ALSO HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE, ESPECIALLY IF ITS PRESENT RATE OF GROWTH PERSISTS.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE STORMING THAT PREVAILED YESTERDAY SUBSIDED VERY EARLY IN THE PERIOD.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TOMORROW FOLLOWED BY TWO DAYS OF ACTIVE CONDITIONS. THE ACTIVE CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED IN RESPONSE TO THE MAJOR FLARE OF 12 NOVEMBER.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 14/2100Z
sections.text: TO 15/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5786 (N13W36) PRODUCED TWO MAJOR FLARES. THE FIRST WAS AN X3/3B AT 15/0659Z ACCOMPANIED BY A 1900 SFU TENFLARE AND TYPES II AND IV RADIO SWEEPS. THE SECOND WAS AN X1/2B AT 15/1939Z. THIS FLARE WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 740 SFU TENFLARE AND TYPES II AND IV RADIO SWEEPS. REGION 5786 MAINTAINED ITS HIGH DEGREE OF MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY IN THE WAKE OF THESE FLARES. REGION 5783 (N18W77) PRODUCED NUMEROUS SUBFLARES AS IT CONTINUED IN A DECAY PHASE. NEW REGIONS 5791 (N28E63) AND 5792 (N10E34) WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: HIGH. REGION 5786 IS LIKELY TO PRODUCE M-CLASS FLARES. AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE IS POSSIBLE FROM THIS REGION. REGIONS 5783 AND 5788 (S15E02) MAY PRODUCE ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 14/2100Z TO 15/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. A SATELLITE LEVEL PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV BEGAN AT 15/0735Z, REACHED A MAXIMUM OF 71 PFU AT 15/0910Z, AND REMAINED IN PROGRESS AT THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE TOMORROW FOLLOWED BY TWO DAYS OF MINOR TO MAJOR STORMING. THE STORMING IS EXPECTED IN RESPONSE TO TODAY'S MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY. ANOTHER INFLUX OF GREATER THAN 10 MEV PARTICLES IS EXPECTED TO ARRIVE NEAR 15/2200Z IN THE WAKE OF TODAY'S X1/2B FLARE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 15/2100Z
sections.text: TO 16/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 5786 (N13W48) PRODUCED AN X1/2B AT 16/1326Z. A 460 SFU TENFLARE, MAJOR TYPE II RADIO SWEEP (EST. SHOCK SPEED 2000 KM/SEC), AND SIGNIFICANT TYPE IV RADIO SWEEP ACCOMPANIED THE FLARE. THE REGION APPEARED TO BE IN A STATE OF GENERAL DECAY, ESPECIALLY IN THE TRAILER PORTION. HOWEVER, THE LEADER PORTION RETAINED ITS VERY COMPLEX MAGNETIC STRUCTURE. REGION 5788 WAS SPLIT INTO TWO SEPARATE REGIONS. THE LEADING SEGMENT RETAINED NUMBER 5788 (S22W12) AND WAS GRADUALLY DECAYING. THE TRAILING PORTION WAS NUMBERED 5793 (S25E03) AND WAS STABLE. IN ADDITION, 5794 (N07W28) AND 5795 (S09E59) WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. THOUGH DECAYING, REGION 5786 EASILY HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR PRODUCING M-CLASS FLARES AND AN ISOLATED X-CLASS FLARE. C-CLASS ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED FROM REGIONS 5788 AND 5793.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 15/2100Z TO 16/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 16/2100Z
sections.text: TO 17/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. THREE M-CLASS EVENTS WERE OBSERVED TODAY FROM REGION 5793 (S22W08). THE FIRST WAS AN M1/1F AT 16/2241Z ACCOMPANIED BY WEAK RADIO BURSTS. THE SECOND WAS AN M1/2B AT 0800Z ACCOMPANIED BY MODERATE RADIO BURSTS. THE THIRD WAS AN M1/SF AT 1323Z. REGION 5786 (N13W64), WHICH PRODUCED MAJOR FLARES ON PREVIOUS DAYS, HAS UNDERGONE SIGNIFICANT DECAY AND PRODUCED ONLY SUBFLARES DURING THE PERIOD. NEW REGION 5696 (N12E63) WAS ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. REGION 5786 IS CONSIDERED TO BE THE MAIN THREAT FOR ACTIVITY, ALTHOUGH REGIONS 5788 (S21W25) AND 5793 (S22W08) ALSO SHOW POTENTIAL FOR PRODUCING LOW LEVEL M-CLASS FLARES. THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR HIGH LEVELS OF ACTIVITY FROM 5786.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 16/2100Z TO 17/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS INITIALLY QUIET BUT ATTAINED MAJOR TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS AFTER A SUDDEN STORM COMMENCEMENT (SSC) OCCURRED AT 0925UT. THE SSC MEASURED 72 GAMMAS IN BOULDER. NUMEROUS MAGNETOPAUSE CROSSINGS WERE OBSERVED AT GEOSTATIONARY ORBIT FROM GOES-7 (W135) AND GOES-6 (W098) DURING THE STORM, INCLUDING AN IMPRESSIVE 3 HOUR PERIOD FROM 1500-1800Z WHEN GOES-7 WAS CONTINUOUSLY OUTSIDE THE MAGNETOSPHERE. THE K-INDEX DURING THAT PERIOD WAS 7. THE MOST LIKELY SOLAR SOURCE FOR THE STORM WAS THE X3 FLARE/CORONAL MASS EJECTION EVENT THAT OCCURRED ON THE 15TH.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MAJOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS AS THE CURRENT DISTURBANCE CONTINUES. ISOLATED PERIODS OF SEVERE STORMING ARE POSSIBLE DURING LOCAL NIGHTTIME HOURS AS A RESULT OF SUBSTORM INJECTIONS. ADDITIONAL INPUT TO THE STORM IS PROB- ABLE SOMETIME TOMORROW AS A RESULT OF THE X1/CME EVENT OB- SERVED ON THE 16TH. THE STORM IS EXPECTED TO SUBSIDE TO MINOR LEVELS ON THE 2ND DAY AND CONDITIONS SHOULD BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE BY THE THIRD DAY.
